div.p: HAving experience that his Maje≈øty, the Being and Operation of all things, appeareth in and to the Creature under a two-fold Form or Vi≈øage, by which that becometh real with the Creature, which is but a ≈øhadow with this Infinite Being: So that from hence it ari≈øeth, the Creature ≈øuppo≈øeth God to be that which is not, and that not to be, which is God.

Therefore hath his Maje≈øty divulged his plea≈øure, that thereby he may take occa≈øion to unfold him≈øelf in and to the Creature under ≈øuch a pro≈øpect, that the Creature may know God, as he is known of God, that ≈øo from the clear appearance of God, the Creature may behold purely what God is, which as yet is manife≈øt, the Creation in this Nation inhabiteth in no other Region then the Woman of Samaria: And therefore it is the cry of his Maje≈øty is not fulfilled and obeyed, but by Churches, Saints, and Devils oppo≈øed and contemned: So that rare it is to find the Creature that is awaked out of his deep ≈øleep, that hath ≈øhaked off the covering, ≈øo that he can from the clear Appearance of God ≈øay, the vail is taken away, and that he believeth the Truth as it is in his Maje≈øty.

In an≈øwer to this, I have travelled from one end of England to another, and as yet could find very few that could define unto me the Object of their Wor≈øhip, or give me a Character what that God is, ≈øo much profe≈ø≈øed by them; yet notwith≈øtanding I could come into no City, Town, nor Village, but there I heard the name God under one Form or another, wor≈øhipped that for God, which I had experience was no God: So that in the period of my Pilgrimage, I concluded there was gods many, and lords many, although to me but one God: Therefore at my return, I was carried out by God to hold forth to the Creature, the God ye≈øterday, to day, and for ever.

To that end, in the peru≈øal of his Maje≈øties plea≈øure, you may take notice what is intended, or rather, in the en≈øuing Treati≈øe recorded, having for the pre≈øent but only pre≈øented to you a Map, in which you may take a full view what that God is thou pretends to Wor≈øhip, whether he be Infinite, or Finite; whether he be ≈øubject to pa≈ø≈øion and affection, whether he behold the actions of the creature as the Creature e≈øteem them, and whether he can be changed by thy prayers, ≈øo as to expiate a judgement, or produce a deliverance, yea whether he be all, and in all, or but all in part, that is to ≈øay, whether one act be good, another evil, one light, another darkne≈øs; and if ≈øo, rea≈øon from Scripture declareth, God is pa≈ø≈øionate, God is affectionate, and if either, then changeable.

But by forms and ≈øpiritual God like forms he is profe≈ø≈øed, and ≈øo wor≈øhipped as a God that beholds evil and good; ≈øo pa≈ø≈øionate with the one, and affectionate with the other, ≈øo that in conclu≈øion they imagine him as them≈øelves, not infinite, but finite, therefore it is, one Act in God is conceived two in them≈øelves, to wit, one Act Adultry, another Hone≈øty; when if Rea≈øon were admitted, and thereby Scripture interpreted, then ≈øhould they ob≈øerve in that Act they call Hone≈øty, to be Adultry, and that Act ≈øo called Adultry, to have as much hone≈øty as the other, for with God they are but one, and that one Act holy, ju≈øt, and good as God; This to me by Rea≈øon is confirmed, and by Scripture declared, That to the pure all things are pure: So that for my part I know nothing unclean to me, no more then it is of it ≈øelf, and therefore what Act ≈øoever I do, is acted by that Maje≈øty in me, as in the en≈øuing Treati≈øe will appear what Acts they are, the nature of Acting them; and in the period: how I e≈øteem them: So that I weigh not how I am judged, in that I judge not my ≈øelf. So to conclude, the cen≈øures of Scripture, Churches, Saints, and Devils, are no more to me than the cuting off of a Dogs neck.

div.p: THe God of gods hath ca≈øt me on this Subject, to the end he may take occa≈øion to unfold him≈øelf what he is in him≈øelf, and how he maketh out him≈øelf in his Appearance to the creature.

To that end, be plea≈øed to peru≈øe the precedent ver≈øes, and you will find what occa≈øioned the≈øe terms in this Text; In brief, you may behold the Original thereof ari≈øe from the pre≈øent ≈øtate of the Gentiles, they being then as it were Pri≈øoners, and in the ≈øtate of darkne≈øs; So that in reference to their bondage, Chri≈øt called the Son of God was promi≈øed, to redeem them from the Region of Darkne≈øs; that notwith≈øtanding they had wor≈øhipped that for God which was no god, yet now is the time come, now is the day that God will plunder them of their Idols, that God will enlighten their dark under≈øtandings, as in my Text, God will make darkne≈øs light before them.

Notwith≈øtanding it may be ≈øuppo≈øed by ≈øome, that the connexion hereof doth only concern the Gentiles, yet let me tell thee, I find that God is not ≈øo limitted in his pen, inke, and paper, but that he can and will make the darkne≈øs of the Jew light, as well as the Gentile; yea, the darkne≈øs of you as any other: for never was there more ≈øuper≈øtition, more darkne≈øs in the Churches than now, therefore never more need to have the light of God expel tho≈øe dark mi≈øts that at this time is ≈øpread over all opinions in the Kingdom: So that now doth the time draw neer
that the ≈øayings in this Text ≈øhall appear in the unfoldings of the Spirit, I will make darkne≈øs light before them.

Being now arived at the wi≈øhed Haven, all the difficulty will be how to unload the Ve≈ø≈øel fraughted with ≈øuch hidden pearls, how to make merchandi≈øe of them, how to unfold this Subject to your capacity, how to give you the mind of God, in ≈øuch terms as God appears in you.

And that the more, I find the unfoldings of God in this, ≈øeem to appear contrary to mo≈øt that is quoted in the Hi≈øtory; I will make darkne≈øs light; How is it po≈ø≈øible, when there is no communion, no corre≈øpondency but enmity? Yea, ≈øo great, that they cannot dwell in one hou≈øe, lodge in one bed, but devour one another; for where darkne≈øs is, light is not, and where light appeareth, darkne≈øs is gone; yet notwith≈øtanding you hear, he will make darkne≈øs light.

So that the fir≈øt thing I mind from hence is, That he will not take darkne≈øs away, and in the room thereof place light, but that which in Scripture is called darkne≈øs, and by the Creature believed darkne≈øs, ≈øhall be made light.
Secondly we ≈øhall enquire, Whether that in Scripture, or by the Creature entituled darkne≈øs, be darkne≈øs with God or no?

To this end you may read Light and Darkne≈øs are both alike to God. So then it appeareth but a darkne≈øs in the Creatures apprehen≈øion, ≈øo but an imagined darkne≈øs; for ≈øaith the Text, God is light, and in him no darkne≈øs. So that you ≈øee, what≈øoever or how≈øoever it is called darkne≈øs in Scripture, yet it is none with God Then

Thirdly, I ≈øhall ≈øearch, Whether that in Scripture or by the Creature called God, admit of any other Title but unus (to wit) One him≈øelf, and if I find there is but one Being, one God, and that all that is be light with God, then ≈øhall I not cea≈øe till I find the Original of Darkne≈øs, what it is, and why it is called darkne≈øs, &c.

Fir≈øt, I find in his Divine Being, in his E≈ø≈øence, there is but one God; the hi≈øtory declareth the ≈øame. I am what I am: I am the Lord, and there is none el≈øe: There is no other God be≈øide me: with varieties of Scriptures to this purpo≈øe. So then, it is
cleer by the Hi≈øtory, That the Being and E≈ø≈øence of God admits not of the plural but ≈øingular.

So that there is but one God, who≈øe Name is Light, ≈øo called God; for, that which God is, is God (to wit) God is light, then that light is God; for what God ≈øaith he is, that is him≈øelf, but God ≈øaith, He is light, therefore Light is God; ≈øo from the Scripture where God ≈øaid Let there be light, it is no more then if he had ≈øaid, Let there be God, and there was God, for God is Light. For,

You have heard the Scripture holds forth but one God, which God is Light; yet the ≈øame Scripture holds forth not only light, but lights; as ver≈øe 14. Let there be Lights, and that Lights in the Firmament of the Heaven: So that God made two great lights, that is to ≈øay, The light of the Sun, the light of the Moon, Stars, fire, and candle. From hence take notice, that though but one God, yet divers Lights, and that all made by God; for he that ≈øaid Let there be light, ≈øaid Let there be Lights; therefore he is called The Father of Lights, &c.
But then how ≈øhall we do with that place, For God is light, not lights; either he mu≈øt be as well lights as light, or el≈øe, that all other lights but one hath a Being and Original be≈øides God.

And if it appear that all lights, or that which is called light, though the light of the candle, be made by God, then the light of the candle is the light of God; but if all that is called light, to wit, the light of the Sun, Moon, Stars, Fire, and Candle, have not their being in God, then not made by God; So it will follow, that there is not onely one, but two gods.

But the Scripture ≈øaith, That God made the Light, and God made the Lights: So that both light and lights were made by God, then had they their being in God; for all that he made were in him, of him, and to him, as well the Sun as the Moon, the Stars, the Fire, and the Candle, as any of them; So that in making of the≈øe, he made nothing but him≈øelf; for God is light, as well the one as the other.

But then, If God be light, then lights; ≈øo that we may as well ≈øay Gods, as God; a God of the Sun, another of the Moon; for in that God is light, he mu≈øt as well be the light of the Moon, as
the light of the Sun, the light of the fire, the candle, as the ≈øtars.

Not denying but God is as well the light of the one, as the light of the other; yet notwith≈øtanding that, God is but one light, and although called lights by God, yet they are but one light in God; to that end he is called The Father of Lights, but one Father, though many lights. So that why they are but one light in God, or God one light, and yet by God called lights, are in reference to their di≈øtinct appearance in tho≈øe ≈øeveral bodies (to wit) the body of the Sun, the body of the Moon; that as you ≈øee notwith≈øtanding ≈øeveral beams from one Sun, yet in their ri≈øe from the Sun, they were but one in the Sun; nay indeed, they were nothing but the Sun, but after they are i≈ø≈øued out of the Sun, one this way, another that way from the Sun, then according to this divers appearance, it is no more called a Sun, but a Beam, not only Beam, but Beams, which when reduced to their being, they are no longer called a Beam, but a Sun.

So why they are called lights, and yet but one light with or in God, who is light, it is but according to its divers appearance, which in the being is but one appearance, becau≈øe he that is the being of the light, is the appearance of the light, in what kind or degree what≈øoever.

So that now you may take notice, and in ≈øome mea≈øure behold what God is, and what is to be under≈øtood by tho≈øe terms, God is light, and light is God; which if it be that light is God, to wit, the light of the Sun, Moon, Stars, Fire, and Candle, which if the light appearing in the≈øe, and held forth by the≈øe, be the light of God, Why may not the whole Creation ≈øay with their brother Jacob, Surely God were in the≈øe, and we knew it not?

Whether it is intended the darkne≈ø≈øe of the night to become the light of the day, or it is the Dark, as in ≈øeveral portions of Scripture is recorded: yea it is intended that you call the darkne≈ø≈øe in the Creature, which darkne≈ø≈øe is ≈øin, hell, and mi≈øery: this darkne≈ø≈øe he will make Light, Heaven, and Felicity; for in God is no darkne≈ø≈øe, ≈øin, nor mi≈øery; yet this will he make Light. To this end you ≈øhall find in Scripture a two-fold Power, to wit, more Powers than one, yet notwith≈øtanding there is no Power but of God, and the Powers that be, are ordained of God.
